                                        Students - AME Conference               Links:       About the Conference    Program    Call for Proposals    Registration    Students    Getting There    Around NYC          AME makes special effort to involve students in our conferences. If you have work in progress or completed work that you would like to present, by all means submit it.    Student-Presenter Conference Grants are available to assist student presenters who have limited financial resources to attend and present their work at the annual conference of the Association for Moral Education. The grants are made possible through the generosity of the Gift-of-Time Foundation. ( More )       New York University's, Dean Brabeck is accepting applications for on-site conference voluenteers. We are asking that current graduate students send inquires directly to Sarah DeMott, sjd311@nyu.edu                    This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©        by New York University. All rights reserved.    Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development - 82 Washington Square East, New York, NY 10003

                                        Preparing and Arriving- AME Conference            Preparing and Arriving  Walking Directions In terms of getting to the session location--the convenient thing is that all of the AME sessions are being held at the NYU: Kimmel Center for University Life , located on Washington Square South between LaGuardia and Thompson Streets. The building number is 60, though you can't miss it--it's ten floors high, and a mix of tan brick and glass. The closest subway connection is the A/C/E (the Blue line), which stops at West Fourth Street and Sixth Avenue. When you reach West Fourth, you come up the station stairs to the street and walk straight ahead to the end of the block (You are walking north/uptown,with Sixth Avenue on your left side.) On the corner you have reached West Fourth Street; turn right and keep going straight. You will cross MacDougall Street where Washington Square Park begins, and West Fourth Street becomes Washington Square South. You will cross Sullivan Street, then Thompson street, and pass the church on your right, which is next to the Kimmel Center. Enter the building, and by the time you need to do this, we will have let everyone know of the exact room locations of each session. For additional travel information please see: AME: Getting Here   Preparing for Your Session  Poster Presentations Poster boards and thumbtacks will be provided. Poster board size is 20 x 30 inches. Roundtable Presentation **Note Roundtable will begin at 4:30-5:45 on Thursday! Paper Sessions An LCD player and power point hook-up will be avaliable for paper sessions; however please bring your own laptop.  Symposium Sessions An LCD player and power point hook-up will be avaliable for paper sessions; however please bring your own laptop.                                         Association for Moral Education 2007 Conference               Links:       About the Conference    PREPARING FOR & ARRIVING TO THE CONFERENCE !! (NEW)    Program    Call for Proposals    Registration    Students    Getting There    Around NYC          "Civic Education, Moral Education, and Democracy in a Global Society"    The AME 2007 conference will be held at New York University on November 15th, 16th, and 17th of 2007.    The theme of this upcoming conference is "Civic Education, Moral Education, and Democracy in a Global Society". This year the conference is co-sponsored by New York University (NYU), Fordham University, Teachers College Columbia, and St. John’s University. The Program Chair is Mary Brabeck, Dean of the Steinhardt School of Education and the program committee includes Rene Arcilla (NYU), Robby Cohen (NYU), James Fraser (NYU), Susan Fuhrman (NYU), Jacqueline Mattis (NYU), Jim Hennessey (Fordham), Ann Higgins D’Alessandro (Fordham), Jerrold Ross (St. John’s University), and Margot Strom (Facing History and Ourselves).    The 32nd annual meeting of the Association for Moral Education                     This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©        by New York University. All rights reserved.    Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development - 82 Washington Square East, New York, NY 10003

You will cross MacDougall Street where Washington Square Park begins, and West Fourth Street becomes Washington Square South. You will cross Sullivan Street, then Thompson street, and pass the church on your right, which is next to the Kimmel Center. Enter the building, and by the time you need to do this, we will have let everyone know of the exact room locations of each session. For additional travel information please see: AME: Getting Here   Preparing for Your Session  Poster Presentations Poster boards and thumbtacks will be provided. Poster board size is 20 x 30 inches. Roundtable Presentation **Note Roundtable will begin at 4:30-5:45 on Thursday! Paper Sessions An LCD player and power point hook-up will be avaliable for paper sessions; however please bring your own laptop.  Symposium Sessions An LCD player and power point hook-up will be avaliable for paper sessions; however please bring your own laptop.                                         Association for Moral Education 2007 Conference               Links:       About the Conference    PREPARING FOR & ARRIVING TO THE CONFERENCE !! (NEW)    Program    Call for Proposals    Registration    Students    Getting There    Around NYC          "Civic Education, Moral Education, and Democracy in a Global Society"    The AME 2007 conference will be held at New York University on November 15th, 16th, and 17th of 2007.    The theme of this upcoming conference is "Civic Education, Moral Education, and Democracy in a Global Society". This year the conference is co-sponsored by New York University (NYU), Fordham University, Teachers College Columbia, and St. John’s University. The Program Chair is Mary Brabeck, Dean of the Steinhardt School of Education and the program committee includes Rene Arcilla (NYU), Robby Cohen (NYU), James Fraser (NYU), Susan Fuhrman (NYU), Jacqueline Mattis (NYU), Jim Hennessey (Fordham), Ann Higgins D’Alessandro (Fordham), Jerrold Ross (St. John’s University), and Margot Strom (Facing History and Ourselves).    The 32nd annual meeting of the Association for Moral Education                     This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©        by New York University. All rights reserved.
